Tweets: America has survived a civil war, two world wars, economic depression, and, yes, pandemics. These are trying times, but as I have said before, history will remember how we dealt with the challenges.

We want Idahoans back to work! 

60-70% of folks on unemployment are making more than they did at their job because of the additional $600 in federal benefits. That’s a disincentive to go back to work.

Idaho already offers Return to Work bonuses!

Thank you @SecBrouillette for visiting the @INL! Brouillette announced the DOE will provide $65 million in research funding to advance 93 nuclear technology projects in 28 states -- including the INL, the nation’s leading nuclear energy research facility.

Good news for the future of our country: Today, the U.S. Senate confirmed President Trump’s 200th judicial appointment - a historic legacy that will shape the courts for years to come.

Had a great day with members of the Idaho legislature. We discussed sovereignty over our water, toured aquifer recharge sites that will help ensure water for future generations, and learned about the UI research that will help support continued multiple uses of our public lands!
Idaho’s unprecedented advances in telehealth and healthcare access this year will be preserved long after COVID-19 with a new executive order.  #IdahoCovid19 #IDLeg #IDGov
I encourage all Idahoans to reflect on this historical day and our future as a country. #Juneteenth
President Trump is looking to Idaho on our Return to Work bonuses. The bonuses are needed to counteract federal programs that disincentivize returning to work so we can continue our economic rebound.

A strong economic rebound cannot occur without workers returning to a job, and the new Return to Work cash bonuses counteract the federal payouts and incentivize our workforce to get back to work safely.
The Return to Work bonuses are Idaho's conservative approach to counteracting enhanced federal benefits that disincentivize workers returning to jobs.

It is our intent to have schools safely reopen across Idaho in the fall, although it may look different than it has in the past. Guidance and resources for reopening will be available to school districts and charter schools in the coming weeks.
Here’s some good information on the face coverings we all should be wearing to keep our economic rebound going strong!

Top economic advisor to @realdonaldtrump and the @whitehouse discusses the benefits of return to work bonuses, a concept we're pursuing in Idaho to help our economic rebound, get people off unemployment, and save taxpayer dollars in the long run.
Join Attorney General Lawrence Wasden and me as we answer your questions on fraud and COVID-19 during an AARP Telephone Town-hall on Tuesday, June 16 at noon Mountain Time.
Way to go, @Idaho_Central!
Thank you to Idaho Forest Group's Athol Mill for hosting a discussion on forestry with representatives from Idaho, the West, and with U.S. Dept. of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue!
This ends the extreme emergency declaration, consolidates much of the actions we have taken to date, and ensures Idaho can continue to access federal assistance to mitigate COVID-19.

My latest disaster emergency proclamation ensures we can respond quickly to COVID-19 in our state in order to protect our citizens, preserve healthcare capacity, and rebound our economy. View the proclamation here:

Protocols are added for long-term care facilities, nightclubs, and employers of people who are at greater risk of COVID-19. The protocols for restaurants were also updated to allow for more than six people at a table along with a few other small changes.

We narrowly met criteria to enter the final stage of our Idaho Rebounds plan to safely and responsibly open the economy in stages. Please continue to strengthen your personal actions to slow the spread of COVID-19 so we can keep Idaho open.

I will host a press conference regarding Stage 4 of Idaho Rebounds at 10 a.m. MT, Thursday, June 11, in Capitol Room EW 42. The conference will be streamed to the public through Idaho Public Television.

We’re directing much of the federal coronavirus relief funds back to our citizens and businesses. Property tax relief, support for businesses, and Return to Work bonuses are among the fiscally conservative concepts we’ve put into action here in Idaho.
Show your support for a safe, healthy, and open Idaho by taking the ONE Idaho Pledge.
Qualified individuals interested in applying for the Fish and Game Commission vacancy are encouraged to submit applications to the Governor’s Office by June 26, 2020.
Join Lt. Gov. @JaniceMcGeachin and me for the AARP telephone town hall 6/9 at 12 pm MT.  Participants can join by dialing toll-free 866-767-0637 or register in advance by visiting . @AARPIdaho

Pres. Trump, White House officials and Congressional Republicans are looking at a program just like the one we rolled out here in Idaho: back-to-work bonuses. The move saves taxpayer resources in the long run and helps us achieve a strong economic rebound.
Our focus is to support our communities and our police, fire, and EMS personnel and ensure there are no reductions in public safety during these unprecedented challenges.

Idaho is leveraging federal coronavirus relief funds to cover local public safety personnel salaries, and giving cities and counties the opportunity to pass on the savings to property taxpayers. The move is expected to provide up to $200 million in property tax relief.

More than 60% of Americans who are out of work due to COVID-19 earn more with the enhanced unemployment benefits than their normal wages. The enhanced benefits are set to expire next month, making it even more important to get Idahoans back to work.

I will host a press conference related to unemployment and Idaho’s economy on Friday, June 5 at 11 a.m. MT in Capitol Room EW42. The press conference will be streamed to the public through Idaho Public Television and online.

I pray for the safety of our citizens and our law enforcement officers. God bless George Floyd and the men and women who are standing up in peace for a fair and equitable criminal justice system in America.

George Floyd’s death is unacceptable. We can all unite around our demand for justice for this innocent man. I’m proud of the Idahoans who have channeled their sorrow and anger in peaceful protest, and I appreciate mayors across Idaho who are helping to manage this situation.

We've been able to get PPE to 2,500 small businesses and nonprofits in the past couple of weeks. Health and the economy are linked - people need to feel safe visiting businesses and returning to work. Visit .
Labor Director Jani Revier and I will answer unemployment questions during an hour-long telephone town-hall hosted by AARP Idaho.
Idaho has met the criteria to advance to Stage 3 of the Idaho Rebounds plan to safely and responsibly reopen Idaho’s economy. #IdahoCOVID19

It’s a beautiful Memorial Day Weekend. Please enjoy it responsibly!

This move is about good government and prudent management of taxpayer dollars. Given the uncertain economic times, we must minimize state borrowing and limit the amount of General Fund that is committed to interest payments on loans.

Health and the economy are not mutually exclusive – they are interconnected. Prosperity and safety are linked. Protecting other citizens is the right thing to do, and our economic rebound depends on it.

In today's primary election, the ballot box is your mailbox! Today is the last day to visit  to register and request your ballot. Return your ballot to your county clerk by June 2. Happy Election Day!

Consumer and employee confidence is needed in order for Idaho’s economy to rebound more quickly. Businesses opening their doors should have operational plans in place to mitigate the risk of spreading COVID-19. New protocols were recently added.

Add Asian giant hornets to the list of things NOT to worry about right now. As of May 7, Idaho has no confirmed reports of Asian giant hornets in the state. Only two specimens have ever been collected in the United States - both in northwest Washington.

I join many in recognizing his contributions to our state with gratitude. My condolences to John's family and the many Idahoans who will miss him.

John's sudden death is a tragic loss not just for his loved ones and colleagues, but for all of Idaho. John was one-of-a-kind. He had a unique way of perceiving and bringing resolution to the diversity of opinion around public lands policy.

Businesses around the state reopen to in-store customers today. Thank you to everyone for complying with the Stay-Home Order and continuing to protect your friends and neighbors by following social distancing guidelines!

May is Mental Health Awareness Month in Idaho. I want to encourage Idahoans to pursue mental health treatment if they need it, provide educated support to struggling loved ones, and offer acceptance of our neighbors living with mental health conditions.

Community spread has not occurred in public health district 2 (north central Idaho) as I stated earlier today. I apologize for the confusion.

Community spread has been confirmed in 17 counties -- Ada, Bannock, Bingham, Bonneville, Blaine, Canyon, Elmore, Gem, Jefferson, Jerome, Kootenai, Lemhi, Madison, Owyhee, Payette, Teton, and Twin Falls counties.

The President's newly released guidelines for phased opening of the economy align with Idaho's decisions and actions to overcome coronavirus.

It is the nature of government to grow and for increased regulations to creep into our lives. My Zero-Based Regulation executive order is designed to prevent the accumulation of costly, ineffective, and outdated regulations over time. #IDLeg #IDpol

I believe our people have greater opportunities to prosper when government limits regulatory hurdles, respects taxpayers by spending their money as efficiently as possible, and focuses as much on the needs of tomorrow as the needs of today. #IDLeg
